abstracts.cdata!:
The Second Land Titling Project, as a
            contributory factor to urban management, will facilitate
            future road plans, associated runoff drainage, and footpath
            plans, within the legal and regulatory frameworks, supported
            by the necessary technical capability. Nonetheless, setting
            land titling (LT) boundaries may potentially come in
            conflict with road widening, or construction lines, where a
            variety of public services could be held up, made more
            expensive, or abandoned altogether, causing serious public
            health consequences. Similarly, illegal landfills, and/or
            when at illegal distances from water courses (thus
            encouraging natural drainage uses), may compromise
            acceptance of LT boundaries, since this issue could have
            serious flooding, and public health consequences. To this
            end, this environmental assessment looks at mitigation
            measures, by ensuring the availability of town plans that
            include land titling maps, revised and approved by the Town
            Planning Office. In addition, mediation at the District
            Governor's level will be available as necessary,
            including administrative support should grievances occur.
            The report further includes an annex regarding social
            impacts, and ethnic peoples assessment, to better understand
            the nature, and behavior of customary land rights among
            various ethnic groups in urban, and peri-urban settings,
            and, how - if at all - could the project affect customary
            land laws.
